column1: that Mr Johnson had "engaged in a deliberate form of dishonesty to the House of Commons" The committee also found "at least some of the relevant information" he provided to the House as he prepared to resign last week, including that ministers had been "unfairly and intentionally misleading the House of Commons" The Independent has learnt that Mr Johnson was at the centre of a row with the then Home Secretary Theresa May over the number of ministerial employees who did not have to register as MPs to vote on the Lib Dem manifesto. The Lib Dem manifesto, which was backed by the party's NEC, claimed that in a "small number" of cases ministerial employees had been given unpaid leave but had "failed to provide sufficient evidence to justify the use of that leave". The committee found that Mr Johnson had "engaged in a deliberate form of dishonesty" to the House of Commons and it said at least some of the relevant information was "strongly suggests" this was an example of "misleading the House of Commons" In his opening statement, Mr Johnson said he believed the committee was "further examining the evidence" and that "we will ensure the case is closed". He said: "We will be looking at the evidence and will look at allegations that have been made against ministers." The committee said Mr Johnson was "engaged in a deliberate form of dishonesty" to the House of Commons and added: "The committee will be looking at the evidence carefully. It will be looking at allegations that have been made against ministers and will be pursuing a more complete and independent review into the matter." Mr Johnson's comments on the Lib Dem manifesto were recorded by a former shadow home secretary, Yvette Cooper, and were published on the website of the Tory peer's party. "I was the MP of Coventry for many years and now I think that there are some things that have been done to this country that have not been done to me," he said. His comments drew parallels with the remarks of Labour MP John Mann, who said there was a "pattern of abuse" by ministers over the past six years.
